messageBody:
Hi Mike,

> From: Michael Rettig [mailto:mrettig@...]
>
> Just make the getIAMSDB() method synchronized with a null
> check. Unless you are in an extremely high-load environment
> with strict performance demands, you'll never notice a
> difference. Also, it allows you to properly throw a runtime
> (or checked) exception when home is not available.

That's exactly what I refactored from:

public static synchronized IAMSDB getIAMSDB()
throws Exception
{
if(theIAMSDB == null)
{
try
{
IAMSDBHome home = (IAMSDBHome)getInitialContext()
.lookup(getJNDIProperty("IAMSDBBean"));
theIAMSDB = home.create();
}
catch(Exception e)
{
e.printStackTrace();
}
}
return theIAMSDB;
}

What's nice about the initialize on demand idiom is that it's one of
those rare cases where the optimization is lucid, simple and safe. But
having to have an ejb container turned on to run my tests doesn't sit
right. I'll roll back for now.

> Another solution is simply to exclude certain classes from
> the filewalker fileset (a custom Ant task works nicely).

Then it's back to bookeeping tests :(

It's a shame. Initialize on demand is a real nice to have for this kind
of stuff or when you're writing plugins.
